column2: Only he, who has ever by accident sniffed vigorously a dose of pepper, can have the faintest conception of the hopeless condition in which such a sniff would reduce any human being.
column3: Only he, who has ever by accident sniffed vigorously a dose of pepper, can have the faintest conception of the hopeless condition in which such a sniff would reduce any human being.

column2: Chauvelin felt as if his head would burst--sneeze after sneeze seemed nearly to choke him; he was blind, deaf, and dumb for the moment, and during that moment Blakeney quietly, without the slightest haste, took up his hat, took some money out of his pocket, which he left on the table, then calmly stalked out of the room!
column3: Chauvelin felt as if his head would burst-sneeze after sneeze seemed nearly to choke him; he was blind, deaf, and dumb for the moment, and during that moment Blakeney quietly, without the slightest haste, took up his hat, took some money out of his pocket, which he left on the table, then calmly stalked out of the room!

column2: CHAPTER XXVI THE JEW

column2: It took Marguerite some time to collect her scattered senses; the whole of this last short episode had taken place in less than a minute, and Desgas and the soldiers were still about two hundred yards away from the "Chat Gris."

column2: When she realised what had happened, a curious mixture of joy and wonder filled her heart.

column2: It all was so neat, so ingenious.

column2: Chauvelin was still absolutely helpless, far more so than he could even have been under a blow from the fist, for now he could neither see, nor hear, nor speak, whilst his cunning adversary had quietly slipped through his fingers.
column3: Chauvelin was still absolutely helpless, far more so than he could even have been under a blow from the fist, for now he could neither see, nor hear, nor speak, whilst his cunning adversary had quietly slipped through his fingers.

column2: Every place was watched, and every stranger kept in sight.

column2: How far could Percy go, thus arrayed in his gorgeous clothes, without being sighted and followed?

column2: The tall stranger--quick!--did any of you see him?

column2: Fortunately, there's not much harm done, or it had fared ill with you, Citoyen Desgas."
column3: Fortunately, there's not much harm done, or it had fared ill with you, Citoyen Desgas."

column2: The tall stranger, citoyen-- he stammered.

column2: For obvious reasons, I dared not tackle him alone. Brogard is too big a fool, and that cursed Englishman appears to have the strength of a bullock, and so he slipped away under your very nose."
column3: For obvious reasons, I dared not tackle him alone. Brogard is too big a fool, and that cursed Englishman appears to have the strength of a bullock, and so he slipped away under your very nose."

column2: He cannot go far without being sighted, citoyen.

column2: That's good.--Do the men know their work? "They have had very clear orders, citoyen: and I myself spoke to those who were about to start. They are to shadow--as secretly as possible--any stranger they may see, especially if he be tall, or stoop as if he would disguise his height."
column3: That's good.--Do the men know their work? "They have had very clear orders, citoyen: and I myself spoke to those who were about to start. They are to shadow-as secretly as possible-any stranger they may see, especially if he be tall, or stoop as if he would disguise his height."

column3: In no case to detain such a person, of course, said Chauvelin, eagerly.

column2: We must let him get to the Pere Blanchard's hut now; there surround and capture him."
column3: We must let him get to the Pere Blanchard's hut now; there surround and capture him."

column3: The men understand that, citoyen, and also that, as soon as a tall stranger has been sighted, he must be shadowed, whilst one man is to turn straight back and report to you.

column2: That is right, said Chauvelin, rubbing his hands, well pleased.

column2: I have further news for you, citoyen.

column2: What is it?
column3: What is it?

column2: A tall Englishman had a long conversation about three-quarters of an hour ago with a Jew, Reuben by name, who lives not ten paces from here.
column3: A tall Englishman had a long conversation about three quarters of an hour ago with a Jew, Reuben by name, who lives not ten paces from here.

column2: Yes--and? queried Chauvelin, impatiently.
column3: Yes-and? queried Chauvelin, impatiently.

column3: The conversation was all about a horse and cart, which the tall Englishman wished to hire, and which was to have been ready for him by eleven o'clock.

column2: It is past that now.	It is past that now.

column2: Where does that Reuben live?"
column3: Where does that Reuben live?"

column2: A few minutes' walk from this door.
column3: A few minutes' walk from this door.

column2: Send one of the men to find out if the stranger has driven off in Reuben's cart.
column3: Send one of the men to find out if the stranger has driven off in Reuben's cart.

column2: Yes, citoyen.
column3: Yes, citoyen.

column2: Desgas went to give the necessary orders to one of the men.
column3: Desgas went to give the necessary orders to one of the men.

column2: Not a word of this conversation between him and Chauvelin had escaped Marguerite, and every word they had spoken seemed to strike at her heart, with terrible hopelessness and dark foreboding.
column3: Not a word of this conversation between him and Chauvelin had escaped Marguerite, and every word they had spoken seemed to strike at her heart, with terrible hopelessness and dark foreboding.

column2: She had come all this way, and with such high hopes and firm determination to help her husband, and so far she had been able to do nothing, but to watch, with a heart breaking with anguish, the meshes of the deadly net closing round the daring Scarlet Pimpernel.
column3: She had come all this way, and with such high hopes and firm determination to help her husband, and so far she had been able to do nothing, but to watch, with a heart breaking with anguish, the meshes of the deadly net closing round the daring Scarlet Pimpernel.

column2: He could not now advance many steps, without spying eyes to track and denounce him.
column3: He could not now advance many steps, without spying eyes to track and denounce him.

column2: Her own helplessness struck her with the terrible sense of utter disappointment.
column3: Her own helplessness struck her with the terrible sense of utter disappointment.

column2: The possibility of being the slightest use to her husband had become almost NIL, and her only hope rested in being allowed to share his fate, whatever it might ultimately be.
column3: The possibility of being the slightest use to her husband had become almost NIL, and her only hope rested in being allowed to share his fate, whatever it might ultimately be.

column2: For the moment, even her chance of ever seeing the man she loved again, had become a remote one.
column3: For the moment, even her chance of ever seeing the man she loved again, had become a remote one.

column2: Still, she was determined to keep a close watch over his enemy, and a vague hope filled her heart, that whilst she kept Chauvelin in sight, Percy's fate might still be hanging in the balance.
column3: Still, she was determined to keep a close watch over his enemy, and a vague hope filled her heart, that whilst she kept Chauvelin in sight, Percy's fate might still be hanging in the balance.

column2: Desgas left Chauvelin moodily pacing up and down the room, whilst he himself waited outside for the return of the man whom he had sent in search of Reuben.
column3: Desgas left Chauvelin moodily pacing up and down the room, whilst he himself waited outside for the return of the man whom he had sent in search of Reuben.

column2: Thus several minutes went by.
column3: Thus several minutes went by.

column2: Chauvelin was evidently devoured with impatience.
column3: Chauvelin was evidently devoured with impatience.

column2: Apparently he trusted no one: this last trick played upon him by the daring Scarlet Pimpernel had made him suddenly doubtful of success, unless he himself was there to watch, direct and superintend the capture of this impudent Englishman.
column3: Apparently he trusted no one: this last trick played upon him by the daring Scarlet Pimpernel had made him suddenly doubtful of success, unless he himself was there to watch, direct and superintend the capture of this impudent Englishman.

column3: About five minutes later, Desgas returned, followed by an elderly Jew, in a dirty, threadbare gaberdine, worn greasy across the shoulders.

column2: His red hair, which he wore after the fashion of the Polish Jews, with the corkscrew curls each side of his face, was plentifully sprinkled with grey--a general coating of grime, about his cheeks and his chin, gave him a peculiarly dirty and loathsome appearance.
column3: His red hair, which he wore after the fashion of the Polish Jews, with the corkscrew curls each side of his face, was plentifully sprinkled with grey-a general coating of grime, about his cheeks and his chin, gave him a peculiarly dirty and loathsome appearance.

column2: He had the habitual stoop, those of his race affected in mock humility in past centuries, before the dawn of equality and freedom in matters of faith, and he walked behind Desgas with the peculiar shuffling gait which has remained the characteristic of the Jew trader in continental Europe to this day.
column3: He had the habitual stoop, those of his race affected in mock humility in past centuries, before the dawn of equality and freedom in matters of faith, and he walked behind Desgas with the peculiar shuffling gait which has remained the characteristic of the Jew trader in continental Europe to this day.

column2: Chauvelin, who had all the Frenchman's prejudice against the despised race, motioned to the fellow to keep at a respectful distance.

column2: Is this the man? asked Chauvelin.
column3: Is this the man? asked Chauvelin.

column2: No, citoyen, replied Desgas, "Reuben could not be found, so presumably his cart has gone with the stranger; but this man here seems to know something, which he is willing to sell for a consideration."
column3: No, citoyen, replied Desgas, "Reuben could not be found, so presumably his cart has gone with the stranger; but this man here seems to know something, which he is willing to sell for a consideration."

column2: Ah! said Chauvelin, turning away with disgust from the loathsome specimen of humanity before him.
column3: Ah! said Chauvelin, turning away with disgust from the loathsome specimen of humanity before him.

column2: The Jew, with characteristic patience, stood humbly on one side, leaning on the knotted staff, his greasy, broad-brimmed hat casting a deep shadow over his grimy face, waiting for the noble Excellency to deign to put some questions to him.
column3: The Jew, with characteristic patience, stood humbly on one side, leaning on the knotted staff, his greasy, broad brimmed hat casting a deep shadow over his grimy face, waiting for the noble Excellency to deign to put some questions to him.

column2: The citoyen tells me, said Chauvelin peremptorily to him, "that you know something of my friend, the tall Englishman, whom I desire to meet . . .
column3: The citoyen tells me, said Chauvelin peremptorily to him, "that you know something of my friend, the tall Englishman, whom I desire to meet . . .

column2: MORBLEU! keep your distance, man," he added hurriedly, as the Jew took a quick and eager step forward.
column3: m o r b l e u! keep your distance, man," he added hurriedly, as the Jew took a quick and eager step forward.

column2: Yes, your Excellency, replied the Jew, who spoke the language with that peculiar lisp which denotes Eastern origin, "I and Reuben Goldstein met a tall Englishman, on the road, close by here this evening."
column3: Yes, your Excellency, replied the Jew, who spoke the language with that peculiar lisp which denotes Eastern origin, "I and Reuben Goldstein met a tall Englishman, on the road, close by here this evening."

column2: Did you speak to him?
column3: Did you speak to him?

column2: He spoke to us, your Excellency.	He spoke to us, your Excellency.

column2: He wanted to know if he could hire a horse and cart to go down along the St. Martin road, to a place he wanted to reach to-night."
column3: He wanted to know if he could hire a horse and cart to go down along the saint Martin road, to a place he wanted to reach to night."

column2: What did you say?
column3: What did you say?

column2: I did not say anything, said the Jew in an injured tone, "Reuben Goldstein, that accursed traitor, that son of Belial . . ."
column3: I did not say anything, said the Jew in an injured tone, "Reuben Goldstein, that accursed traitor, that son of Belial . . ."

column2: Cut that short, man, interrupted Chauvelin, roughly, "and go on with your story."
column3: Cut that short, man, interrupted Chauvelin, roughly, "and go on with your story."

column2: He took the words out of my mouth, your Excellency: when I was about to offer the wealthy Englishman my horse and cart, to take him wheresoever he chose, Reuben had already spoken, and offered his half-starved nag, and his broken-down cart.
column3: He took the words out of my mouth, your Excellency: when I was about to offer the wealthy Englishman my horse and cart, to take him wheresoever he chose, Reuben had already spoken, and offered his half starved nag, and his broken down cart.

column2: And what did the Englishman do?
column3: And what did the Englishman do?

column2: He listened to Reuben Goldstein, your Excellency, and put his hand in his pocket then and there, and took out a handful of gold, which he showed to that descendant of Beelzebub, telling him that all that would be his, if the horse and cart were ready for him by eleven o'clock.
column3: He listened to Reuben Goldstein, your Excellency, and put his hand in his pocket then and there, and took out a handful of gold, which he showed to that descendant of Beelzebub, telling him that all that would be his, if the horse and cart were ready for him by eleven o'clock.

column2: And, of course, the horse and cart were ready?
column3: And, of course, the horse and cart were ready?

column2: Well! they were ready for him in a manner, so to speak, your Excellency.	Well! they were ready for him in a manner, so to speak, your Excellency.

column2: Reuben's nag was lame as usual; she refused to budge at first.
column3: Reuben's nag was lame as usual; she refused to budge at first.

column3: It was only after a time and with plenty of kicks, that she at last could be made to move," said the Jew with a malicious chuckle.

column2: Then they started?
column3: Then they started?

column2: I was disgusted with that stranger's folly.
column3: I was disgusted with that stranger's folly.

column2: An Englishman too!--He ought to have known Reuben's nag was not fit to drive."
column3: An Englishman too!--He ought to have known Reuben's nag was not fit to drive."

column3: But if he had no choice?

column3: No choice, your Excellency? protested the Jew, in a rasping voice, "did I not repeat to him a dozen times, that my horse and cart would take him quicker, and more comfortably than Reuben's bag of bones.

column2: He would not listen.

column2: Reuben is such a liar, and has such insinuating ways. The stranger was deceived.

column3: You have a horse and cart too, then? asked Chauvelin, peremptorily.

column3: Aye! that I have, your Excellency, and if your Excellency wants to drive . . .

column2: Marguerite's heart was beating well-nigh to bursting.

column3: Twenty francs, your Excellency, replied the Jew, "and I have been an honest man all my life."

column2: Will your Excellency deign to look."

column3: On the road which the Englishman took, Miquelon is the nearest village, not two leagues from here.

column2: There he could get fresh conveyance, if he wanted to go further?
column3: There he could get fresh conveyance, if he wanted to go further?

column2: He could--if he ever got so far.
column3: He could-if he ever got so far.

column2: Can you?
column3: Can you?

column2: Will your Excellency try? said the Jew simply.
column3: Will your Excellency try? said the Jew simply.

column2: That is my intention, said Chauvelin very quietly, "but remember, if you have deceived me, I shall tell off two of my most stalwart soldiers to give you such a beating, that your breath will perhaps leave your ugly body for ever.
column3: That is my intention, said Chauvelin very quietly, "but remember, if you have deceived me, I shall tell off two of my most stalwart soldiers to give you such a beating, that your breath will perhaps leave your ugly body for ever.

column2: But if we find my friend the tall Englishman, either on the road or at the Pere Blanchard's hut, there will be ten more gold pieces for you.
column3: But if we find my friend the tall Englishman, either on the road or at the Pere Blanchard's hut, there will be ten more gold pieces for you.

column2: Do you accept the bargain?"
column3: Do you accept the bargain?"

column2: The Jew again thoughtfully rubbed his chin.
column3: The Jew again thoughtfully rubbed his chin.

column2: He looked at the money in his hand, then at this stern interlocutor, and at Desgas, who had stood silently behind him all this while.
column3: He looked at the money in his hand, then at this stern interlocutor, and at Desgas, who had stood silently behind him all this while.

column2: After a moment's pause, he said deliberately,--
column3: After a moment's pause, he said deliberately,--

column2: I accept.
column3: I accept.

column2: Go and wait outside then, said Chauvelin, "and remember to stick to your bargain, or by Heaven, I will keep to mine."
column3: Go and wait outside then, said Chauvelin, "and remember to stick to your bargain, or by Heaven, I will keep to mine."

column2: With a final, most abject and cringing bow, the old Jew shuffled out of the room.
column3: With a final, most abject and cringing bow, the old Jew shuffled out of the room.

column2: Chauvelin seemed pleased with his interview, for he rubbed his hands together, with that usual gesture of his, of malignant satisfaction.
column3: Chauvelin seemed pleased with his interview, for he rubbed his hands together, with that usual gesture of his, of malignant satisfaction.

column2: My coat and boots, he said to Desgas at last.
column3: My coat and boots, he said to Desgas at last.

column2: Desgas went to the door, and apparently gave the necessary orders, for presently a soldier entered, carrying Chauvelin's coat, boots, and hat.
column3: Desgas went to the door, and apparently gave the necessary orders, for presently a soldier entered, carrying Chauvelin's coat, boots, and hat.

column2: He took off his soutane, beneath which he was wearing close-fitting breeches and a cloth waistcoat, and began changing his attire.
column3: He took off his soutane, beneath which he was wearing close fitting breeches and a cloth waistcoat, and began changing his attire.

column2: You, citoyen, in the meanwhile, he said to Desgas, "go back to Captain Jutley as fast as you can, and tell him to let you have another dozen men, and bring them with you along the St. Martin Road, where I daresay you will soon overtake the Jew's cart with myself in it.
column3: You, citoyen, in the meanwhile, he said to Desgas, "go back to Captain Jutley as fast as you can, and tell him to let you have another dozen men, and bring them with you along the saint Martin Road, where I daresay you will soon overtake the Jew's cart with myself in it.

column2: There will be hot work presently, if I mistake not, in the Pere Blanchard's hut.
column3: There will be hot work presently, if I mistake not, in the Pere Blanchard's hut.

column2: We shall corner our game there, I'll warrant, for this impudent Scarlet Pimpernel has had the audacity--or the stupidity, I hardly know which--to adhere to his original plans.
column3: We shall corner our game there, I'll warrant, for this impudent Scarlet Pimpernel has had the audacity-or the stupidity, I hardly know which-to adhere to his original plans.

column2: He has gone to meet de Tournay, St. Just and the other traitors, which for the moment, I thought, perhaps, he did not intend to do.
column3: He has gone to meet de Tournay, st Just and the other traitors, which for the moment, I thought, perhaps, he did not intend to do.

column2: When we find them, there will be a band of desperate men at bay.
column3: When we find them, there will be a band of desperate men at bay.

column2: Some of our men will, I presume, be put HORS DE COMBAT.
column3: Some of our men will, I presume, be put HORS DE COMBAT.

column2: These royalists are good swordsmen, and the Englishman is devilish cunning, and looks very powerful.
column3: These royalists are good swordsmen, and the Englishman is devilish cunning, and looks very powerful.

column2: Still, we shall be five against one at least.
column3: Still, we shall be five against one at least.

column2: You can follow the cart closely with your men, all along the St. Martin Road, through Miquelon.
column3: You can follow the cart closely with your men, all along the saint Martin Road, through Miquelon.

column2: The Englishman is ahead of us, and not likely to look behind him."
column3: The Englishman is ahead of us, and not likely to look behind him."

column2: Whilst he gave these curt and concise orders, he had completed his change of attire.
column3: Whilst he gave these curt and concise orders, he had completed his change of attire.

column2: The priest's costume had been laid aside, and he was once more dressed in his usual dark, tight-fitting clothes.
column3: The priest's costume had been laid aside, and he was once more dressed in his usual dark, tight fitting clothes.

column2: At last he took up his hat.
column3: At last he took up his hat.

column2: I shall have an interesting prisoner to deliver into your hands, he said with a chuckle, as with unwonted familiarity he took Desgas' arm, and led him towards the door.
column3: I shall have an interesting prisoner to deliver into your hands, he said with a chuckle, as with unwonted familiarity he took Desgas' arm, and led him towards the door.

column2: We won't kill him outright, eh, friend Desgas?	We won't kill him outright, eh, friend Desgas?
column3: false

column2: The Pere Blanchard's hut is--an I mistake not--a lonely spot upon the beach, and our men will enjoy a bit of rough sport there with the wounded fox.
column3: The Pere Blanchard's hut is-an I mistake not-a lonely spot upon the beach, and our men will enjoy a bit of rough sport there with the wounded fox.

column2: Choose your men well, friend Desgas . . . of the sort who would enjoy that type of sport--eh?
column3: Choose your men well, friend Desgas . . . of the sort who would enjoy that type of sport-eh?

column2: We must see that Scarlet Pimpernel wither a bit--what?--shrink and tremble, eh? . . . before we finally . . ." He made an expressive gesture, whilst he laughed a low, evil laugh, which filled Marguerite's soul with sickening horror.
column3: We must see that Scarlet Pimpernel wither a bit-what?--shrink and tremble, eh? . . . before we finally . . ." He made an expressive gesture, whilst he laughed a low, evil laugh, which filled Marguerite's soul with sickening horror.

column2: Choose your men well, Citoyen Desgas, he said once more, as he led his secretary finally out of the room.
column3: Choose your men well, Citoyen Desgas, he said once more, as he led his secretary finally out of the room.
